title: 8 Common Mistakes When Learning Soroban (And How to Fix Them)
description: Avoid these typical soroban learning pitfalls that slow progress. Most are easy to fix once you know what to look for.
imageAlt: Common soroban learning mistakes to avoid

content.intro: After helping thousands of kids learn soroban, we've seen the same mistakes over and over. Here are the most common ones â€“ and how to correct them before they become habits.

sections.text: Mistake 1: Practicing Too Long
**The problem:** Parents think more is better. 45-minute sessions lead to burnout.
**The fix:** 15-20 minutes daily beats 60 minutes twice a week. Short, consistent sessions build neural pathways better than marathon sessions.
Mistake 2: Skipping Fundamentals
**The problem:** Rushing to impressive multi-digit problems before mastering basics.
**The fix:** Spend extra time on single-digit addition until accuracy is 90%+. A weak foundation creates problems that compound later.
Mistake 3: Wrong Finger Usage
**The problem:** Using all fingers, or using index finger to push beads up (should use thumb).
**The fix:** Thumb pushes lower beads UP. Index finger pushes beads DOWN. Gently correct early, don't stress about perfection.
Mistake 4: Counting Beads Instead of Recognizing Patterns
**The problem:** "One, two, three..." counting every bead instead of instant recognition.
**The fix:** Practice number recognition games. Show a pattern, child says the number immediately. Speed will develop with repetition.
Mistake 5: Skipping the Reset
**The problem:** Starting new problems without clearing the soroban first.
**The fix:** Always reset all beads away from the beam before each new problem. This builds clean habits and prevents confusion.
Mistake 6: Moving to Anzan Too Early
**The problem:** Trying mental calculation before physical technique is automatic.
**The fix:** Spend 3-6 months on physical soroban before introducing mental math (anzan). The visualization needs a strong physical foundation.
Mistake 7: Inconsistent Practice
**The problem:** 5 days on, 10 days off, 3 days on... erratic schedules.
**The fix:** Same time every day, even if just 10 minutes. Consistency builds habit. Habit builds skill.
Link practice to an existing routine: after breakfast, before screen time, etc. Habit stacking works.
Mistake 8: Focusing on Speed Over Accuracy
**The problem:** Racing through problems, making careless errors.
**The fix:** Accuracy first, THEN speed. A wrong answer at lightning speed is still wrong. Speed comes naturally after accuracy is solid.
Every one of these mistakes is fixable. Don't panic if your child has some of these habits. Gentle, consistent correction works.

faq.question: What if bad habits are already formed?
faq.answer: They can be unlearned, it just takes longer. Go back to basics, practice correctly at a slower pace, and gradually rebuild.

faq.question: How do I know which mistakes my child is making?
faq.answer: Watch them practice occasionally. Check app accuracy stats. If accuracy is low or progress stalled, investigate.

faq.question: Should I correct every mistake immediately?
faq.answer: Pick 1-2 to focus on at a time. Too many corrections are overwhelming and discouraging.
